title: Croup
summary: Viral infection causing barking cough and breathing difficulty in children. Steam and cool air can help relieve symptoms.

steps.title: Recognize Croup
steps.description: Distinctive barking seal-like cough, hoarse voice, noisy breathing (stridor), worse at night. Child may have mild fever and cold symptoms. Most common in children 6 months to 3 years.

steps.title: Keep Child Calm
steps.description: Comfort and calm child - crying makes breathing worse. Hold child upright in your lap. Speak softly and reassuringly. Anxiety worsens airway constriction. Stay calm yourself.

steps.title: Use Steam or Cool Air
steps.description: Run hot shower to create steam bathroom. Sit with child for 10-15 minutes. OR take child outside in cool night air for 10 minutes. Both can reduce airway swelling. Repeat as needed.

steps.title: Keep Child Hydrated
steps.description: Offer cool fluids frequently - water, popsicles, or juice. Avoid dairy which can thicken mucus. Use humidifier in child's room. Prop child up with pillows for easier breathing during sleep.

steps.title: Monitor Breathing
steps.description: Watch for: severe breathing difficulty, blue lips/face, drooling or unable to swallow, high fever, dehydration. Call 911 if child struggles to breathe, makes whistling sound, or seems very ill.

warnings: Severe croup can block airway - monitor breathing closely
Never give cough medicine to children under 4
Symptoms often worse at night for several nights
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 if child has severe breathing difficulty or blue color
See doctor same day for persistent barking cough
Seek immediate care if child is drooling or can't swallow
preventionTips: Wash hands frequently to prevent viral infections
Keep child away from cigarette smoke
